posts.name: Logan de Laar
posts.cooked: My team is working on a ground intake and right now we are working on detecting when we have the coral. I am not the coder however I do know we are having trouble with the current detection. We have a lidar further up in the intake however, the sooner we detect the coral, the faster the cycles. Does anyone have any suggestions on how we can either tune the current detection to be better, or any other means of detection?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: What does a plot of your current look like while you are intaking a coral? What does it look like if you are intaking but don’t touch a coral? What does it look like if you run into a wall? Does it look the same every time? What is the variability? These are all things that matter a lot to do what you are talking about in code and also vary wildly between different intakes (even of the same style).

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: I think battery voltage changes the current signature, also. Do you have a tunable lidar? You can place more proximity switches at the point that you say the intaking is complete. The Pololu IR sensors are less than $20 each (and there are many other kinds that CD posters have recommended) and I suggest two - one on each side or straight-on works too if that’s how you have to mount them.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
For the ground intake, I’d be inclined to also check the rotation speed of the mechanism and expect that the rotation speed will decrease during an intake (and during a collision with another robot )

For either, consider whether you need to increase the update frequency of the status signaling.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
As @olsonkarlp suggested, look at the current over time for all the valid modes of operation.

What you want to look for is a large step in the current. Depending on what your system is doing, it could be a positive (increasing) going step or a negative (decreasing) going step that correlates to some condition you want to sense. Using a large step gets around issues such as noise and battery voltage variations. You can choose threshold value at around half value of the step.

It may be necessary to add some time delay to get exactly the result you want.

a beambreak/IR sensor is nice and pretty easy, although specifically how you’d do that probably depends on the geometry of your intake. as for using current, we used the WPILib linear filter class + debouncing to filter out noise, which worked pretty well

link_counts.title: Linear Filters — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Abdullah Khaled
posts.cooked:
We had a 2910-style intake last year, so the code may be different, but the detect slower rotation method worked really well for us: FRC_REEFSCAPE2025_V2/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/IntakeSubsystem.java at offseason-dev · itkan-robotics/FRC_REEFSCAPE2025_V2 · GitHub

I know I yoinked the code from 3467, but I couldn’t find it for the life of me (mobile user woes )

posts.name: Fatema M
posts.cooked:
We did not have a ground intake for coral last year, but we used IR sensors and for current detection in our code we used a LoggedTunableNumber to represent the current and the current threshold to know that we have collected the coral.

This preseason however, for coral ground intake, we are using 4 CTRE CANrange sensors so maybe that will help us detect coral faster.

I hope this helps, and reach out with any questions!

posts.name: Logan de Laar
posts.cooked:
Thank you all for the timely feedback, I think our coder is working on a specifics typeup, however, a thing to add for clarification: Fist, we do have a lidar, it is just not right at the edge of the intake, too many moving parts to put it closer (see photo attached). IMG_0016 617×1342 158 KB

IMG_0016 617×1342 158 KB

IMG_0016 617×1342 158 KB

posts.name: Tori Dell
posts.cooked:
Hi! 5000’s code captain here. The issue I’m having is mainly that the current spike is not big enough (around 15-20A if i remember correctly) compared to the signal noise and so with the threshold where it is now we get both false positives where it barely touches the coral and thinks it has the coral before intaking, and also false negatives where it doesn’t detect the coral at all.

To be specific, we are using CTRE status signals updating definitely frequently enough. It waits a little bit for the intake to spin up before starting to detect coral based on if torque current goes above current threshold. The signal is also debounced by 0.1 sec. I’d say around 60% of the time it works, 10% are false positives, and 40% are false negatives.

Also, the dip in rotation speed is minimal compared to the noise from mechanism jitter and robot movement so that’s also not a viable option.

Finally, the main concern with a lidar or beam break is FOV, because i believe the FOV on the Polou lidars is about 10-15 degrees, which could possibly clip the wheels or bumper.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
I’ve used the AdaFruit IR BreakBeam sensors for this with great success. Sometimes these can be too close to harms way though

If current spikes are not working for you maybe try motor RPM changes as a detection effort.
